meanings.definition: A cell or group of cells that receive stimuli.
meanings.sent1: The receptors on the skin help us feel touch.
meanings.sent2: Doctors study how receptors in the body respond to different signals.
meanings.sent3: The receptors in the ears must have a party when we listen to music!
meanings.sent4: Her receptors for kindness are always open and welcoming.
meanings.sent5: The receptors in the nose can detect even the faintest scents.

meanings.definition: A nerve ending that responds to stimuli.
meanings.sent1: When you touch something hot, the receptors in your skin send a warning to your brain.
meanings.sent2: The receptors in the fingertips help us feel textures and temperatures.
meanings.sent3: The receptors in the feet must be the first to know when tickled!
meanings.sent4: His receptors for danger tingled as he walked down the dark alley.
meanings.sent5: The receptors in the eyes can detect even the slightest movement.

meanings.definition: A protein molecule on the surface of a cell that binds to specific substances.
meanings.sent1: The receptors on the cell membrane act like gatekeepers, allowing only certain molecules to enter.
meanings.sent2: Scientists are studying how receptors on cancer cells interact with medications.
meanings.sent3: The receptors on the cell must feel like bouncers at a club, only letting in VIP molecules!
meanings.sent4: Her receptors for love seemed to attract only toxic relationships.
meanings.sent5: The receptors on the tongue can distinguish between different tastes.
